Thursday, 02. June 2022

1Kosmos BlockID

Verizon 2022 Data Breach Investigations Report

This week, Verizon released its DBIR report marking 15 years of the annual report. In the report, Verizon highlighted their analysis of more than 5,212 breaches and 23,896 security incidents to find that attackers have four key paths to enterprise estates; credentials, phishing, exploiting vulnerabilities, and malicious botnets. They go on to state that hackers … Continued The post Verizon 2022

This week, Verizon released its DBIR report marking 15 years of the annual report. In the report, Verizon highlighted their analysis of more than 5,212 breaches and 23,896 security incidents to find that attackers have four key paths to enterprise estates; credentials, phishing, exploiting vulnerabilities, and malicious botnets.

They go on to state that hackers exploit the human element (including errors, misuse and social engineering). Combining this element and the entry points above, hackers gain access to organizations to launch their attacks. In fact, Verizon states that 82% of intrusions this year were related to that human element which included – errors, misuse, and social engineering. In addition, the Verizon research broke down the factors leveraged in a breach:

45% were related to credential reuse 25% were related to social engineering 50% were related to remote access and web applications

The takeaway here is the fact that humans (re. employees) are still the weak link in the security chain. Why? Because users continue to click malicious links, they continue to “lose” or give away their credentials. Users are still making poor security decisions and as a result, hackers are gaining access to applications, systems, and data. While that likely is not a surprise to anyone the numbers make this abundantly clear. As they do most years. And while these reports can be all doom and gloom, fear not, it’s not all bad, because there are ways to fix the problem.

While eliminating the human element sounds challenging for organizations, there are options. Verizon recommends the usual approach to solve some of these problems like deploying two-factor authentication and/or implementing password managers for users, all in an effort to avoid the impact credentials introduce. This approach can reduce the likelihood of attackers being able to exploit poor passwords to gain access to applications, systems, and data. These capabilities have been available and in production for years BUT we are still seeing similar numbers year over year from reports like this year’s DBIR.

Let’s focus on credentials. Why? If you do a quick search for the term in the report it appears 86 times! With that in mind, the report states: “Unfortunately, if you can access the asset directly over the internet simply by entering the credentials, so can the criminals.” So if we can improve upon authenticating users without the use of credentials then I’d argue organizations will be better for it.

How can the use of credentials be improved over the recommendations? Eliminating as many of them as possible. But how? It sounds complicated and even impossible! But that’s simply not the case. Take for instance what 1Kosmos customers can do. Our customers systematically replace credentials with real biometrics that are matched to a verified digital identity and it works across all operating systems including Microsoft, Mac, Unix, and Linux.

How can credentials be replaced? With identity. By combining identity verification with access management organizations can eliminate credentials, especially passwords and therefore, prevent most of the 82% of intrusions caused by humans. This would then free up organizations to place focus on other areas that inject more security risk.

Hopefully, more organizations will take this approach and next year we’ll see a decline in these human-based errors.

The post Verizon 2022 Data Breach Investigations Report appeared first on 1Kosmos.

21:01 • 5 days ago

Anonym

Progress on US-EU Cross-Border Data Transfers: New Agreement to Replace Privacy Shield After Schrems II Ruling

Personal data between the United States and the European Union might soon be flowing smoothly again after the two jurisdictions agreed in principle to a new privacy framework. Data transfers between the EU and the US have been problematic for some time due to a conflict between US surveillance laws and EU data protection and privacy regulations. […] The post Progress on US-EU Cross-Bor
Personal data between the United States and the European Union might soon be flowing smoothly again after the two jurisdictions agreed in principle to a new privacy framework.

Data transfers between the EU and the US have been problematic for some time due to a conflict between US surveillance laws and EU data protection and privacy regulations. In July 2020 the Court of Justice of the European Union invalidated Privacy Shield, an arrangement that had allowed more than 5,000 US companies to conduct transatlantic trade while complying with EU data protection rules. The landmark ruling, informally known as Schrems II after Max Schrems, the lawyer and privacy advocate who filed the original complaint against Facebook with the Irish Data Protection Commissioner, struck down Privacy Shield on the basis that US surveillance programs (signals intelligence activities such as wiretapping phone calls, SMS, and any type of data transfer) went beyond what was strictly necessary and EU citizens had no “actionable judicial redress” or effective remedy in the US. In a nutshell, Privacy Shield didn’t protect Europeans from US surveillance. The decision meant companies and regulators have had to approach data transfers on a case-by-case basis to determine whether they’re meeting EU standards, which hampers trade and increases their compliance burden. 

Further back from Privacy Shield, though, was Safe Harbor, which Europe’s top court also invalidated over “the same core clash between EU privacy rights and US surveillance laws” following a case also put by Max Schrems. Tech Crunch explained: “Putting a little more meat on the bones, the US’ prioritizing of digital surveillance — as revealed by the 2013 revelations of NSA whistleblower, Edward Snowden; and writ large in the breadth of data capture powers allowed by Section 702 of FISA (Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act) and executive order 12,333 (which sanctions bulks collection) — collides directly with European fundamental rights which give citizens rights to privacy and data protection, as set out in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Convention on Human Rights and specific pieces of pan-EU legislation (such as the General Data Protection Regulation).”

Facebook (cited in the Schrems case) and other big data companies like Google were particularly hard hit by the loss of smooth transatlantic data flows. Meta has threatened to shut down Facebook and Instagram in Europe over the data transfers uncertainty in recent years.

At the time of the Schrems II ruling, the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP) made the point that data protection is incredibly important to global commerce, and privacy professionals play a critical role in implementing protections in line with foreign legal requirements.

What the new agreement means

The new privacy framework, agreed to in principle by the US and the European Commission, brings to a head a couple years of legal wrangling and offers the potential for easier cross-border data transfers going forward, especially for Meta and Google and the thousands of other companies that rely on smooth data flows for trade.

In announcing the new deal in late March, President Biden said, “This framework underscores our shared commitment to privacy, to data protection, and to the rule of law,” and that the flow of data would “help facilitate $7.1 trillion in economic relationships with the EU.” 

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen added that the new agreement would “enable predictable and trustworthy data flows between the EU and US, safeguarding privacy and civil liberties.” 

Nick Clegg, Meta’s president of global affairs, said the deal “will provide invaluable certainty for American and European companies of all sizes, including Meta, who rely on transferring data quickly and safely.”

Nick Clegg has previously summarized the data transfers issue in strong terms as “the global internet fragmenting”. 

Google’s president of global affairs, Kent Walker, also welcomed the development: “People want to be able to use digital services from anywhere in the world and know that their information is safe and protected when they communicate across borders.” 

But we’re not out of the woods on this issue yet. This new agreement is expected to be heavily tested with legal challenges, some of which Schrems himself indicates he might launch, saying the “final text” of the new agreement would take more time to come through, and that he was prepared to challenge it “if it is not in line with EU law.”

“In the end, the [EU] Court of Justice will decide a third time. We expect this to be back at the Court within months from a final decision,” Schrems said in a statement on the web site of his privacy non-profit noyb.

The detail as it currently stands

In the White House fact sheet on the new privacy framework, we glean some of the key detail that was missing when the deal was first announced:

The new agreement is officially called the Trans-Atlantic Data Privacy Framework, and promises to be “a durable and reliable legal basis for data flows”, fostering transatlantic data transfers and addressing the concerns raised in the Schrems II decision.  The framework commits the US to “implement new safeguards to ensure that signals intelligence activities are necessary and proportionate in the pursuit of defined national security objectives, which will ensure the privacy of EU personal data and to create a new mechanism for EU individuals to seek redress if they believe they are unlawfully targeted by signals intelligence activities.” The framework will benefits citizens and companies in both the US and EU. “For EU individuals, the deal includes new, high-standard commitments regarding the protection of personal data. For citizens and companies on both sides of the Atlantic, the deal will enable the continued flow of data that underpins more than $1 trillion in cross-border commerce every year, and will enable businesses of all sizes to compete in each other’s markets.”  The White House says the United States has made “unprecedented commitments to:

Strengthen the privacy and civil liberties safeguards governing US signals intelligence activities; Establish a new redress mechanism with independent and binding authority; and Enhance its existing rigorous and layered oversight of signals intelligence activities.”
It gives examples of the new framework’s assurances such as:

“Signals intelligence collection may be undertaken only where necessary to advance legitimate national security objectives, and must not disproportionately impact the protection of individual privacy and civil liberties; EU individuals may seek redress from a new multi-layer redress mechanism that includes an independent Data Protection Review Court that would consist of individuals chosen from outside the US Government who would have full authority to adjudicate claims and direct remedial measures as needed; and US intelligence agencies will adopt procedures to ensure effective oversight of new privacy and civil liberties standards.” 

The White House says any company or organization that uses the new framework to legally protect data flows must continue to adhere to the Privacy Shield Principles, including the requirement to self-certify their adherence to the Principles through the US Department of Commerce. EU individuals will continue to have access to “multiple avenues of recourse to resolve complaints about participating organizations, including through alternative dispute resolution and binding arbitration.”

What we think of this development

This is an important issue to be across if you do business outside the US. We believe this new privacy framework is necessary, and we’re pleased to see progress on this long-running issue.

Reading the fact sheet from the White House, it sounds like the US had to make concessions in the main areas that the EU court had issues with: US signals intelligence activities and a perception of lack of oversight and proportionality.

The requirement on companies and organizations to continue to self-certify adherence to the Privacy Shield Principles is something Anonyome Labs already does and will continue to do.

We believe Max Schrems and his privacy non-profit noyb will challenge again in the European Court of Justice. And, of course, it’s still for the US to demonstrate in practice that they’ve made real change. We hope this new agreement is not just buying a couple more years on the merry go round.

Photo by Serhii Yevdokymov

The post Progress on US-EU Cross-Border Data Transfers: New Agreement to Replace Privacy Shield After Schrems II Ruling appeared first on Anonyome Labs.

11:12 • 5 days ago

Monetha

What Stores Give Cash Back: 27 Great Options to Earn Money

Cash back is a way stores reward their customers and clients when they purchase items from them. You can avail yourself of it through your credit cards, debit cards, or by using specific apps and websites. A cash back program allows you as a cardholder or account owner to refund a certain percentage of the purchase you have made using a credit or debit card or a personal check. Why Do Store

Cash back is a way stores reward their customers and clients when they purchase items from them. You can avail yourself of it through your credit cards, debit cards, or by using specific apps and websites.

A cash back program allows you as a cardholder or account owner to refund a certain percentage of the purchase you have made using a credit or debit card or a personal check.

Why Do Stores Offer Cash Back?

This marketing strategy encourages account owners to utilize their cards and personal accounts in specific applications to conduct purchases with their cards and apps. In this way, financial transactions stay within the terms of their banking system. This scheme is one of the ways banks advertise their company’s products and services.

What Line of Stores Offer Cash Back?

E stablishments that fulfil our everyday needs such as grocery stores, gas stations, and even department stores offer cash backs. However, it’s rare to find clothing stores, home goods stores, and home furnishing stores that offer cashback promos to their customers.

If you want to avail cashback promo, it is essential to fairly be straightforward about your intent of availing cashback before making a purchase. This can definitely put you at the advantage of being aware of the store’s welcoming policies on cash backs.

Several lines of stores are within the country offer cash backs. They can give you cashback if you use your debit card to purchase from their racks rather than credit cards or bills.

How do Customers Benefit from a Cash Back?

Cashback brings a host of benefits in terms of saving money or even putting customers up for loyalty programs. The greatest utility is that a part of what you spend is given back to you.

It also saves the customers from making errands to the nearest ATM and to servicing banks, as the same stores allow them to avail of the cashback with no fees at all. The fee waiver becomes invalid if they transact from differing branches of banks and ATMs.

In addition, most stores offering cash backs allow you to withdraw from your checking account through their stores. But of course, it has limits. Should you need cash for a family gathering tomorrow, it is best to go to the nearest branch of your bank. These stores often give money back with minimal to no minimum purchase.

Stores That Offer Cash back

Now that we have a fair idea of how to receive cashback and save bucks, it is helpful to identify some stores that give cashback to its customers for a variety of purchases.

1. Albertsons

The store offers cashback to a maximum of $300.00 if you use your debit card for making a purchase. They also offer cashback for credit cards, mainly to Discover Credit Card owners, for up to $120.00. The store also has unique services, including unlimited Free delivery, gift cards, coupons, and return facilities.

2. Aldi

Aldi offers cashback within their stores in the US if you purchase and pay through your debit card or Discover Credit Card. They will give as much as $100.00. You can avail the cash back without any charge if you will be paying through your card.

Aldi has only specified amounts of cashback that you can avail of. It can only be in monetary valuations of $10,$20, $40, or $100. They do not allow customers to customize other amounts for cashback; employing this procedure will enable Aldi to maintain their efficient and super speedy check-out counters.

Their cashback limit stays within the maximum of $100.00, but if you need a higher amount of cash, you can try splitting your purchases into two payments on the counter. Other options are to go to the nearest ATM booth, your bank, or another store that allows higher cashback.

3. Food Lion

It is one of the biggest chains of stores in the United States, started in 1957. The store now has more than a thousand branches in ten different states of the US. Food lion is one store that provides cashback to its customers for as much as $200.00.

They give cashback in the store if you pay through your debit cards or your payroll checks on their check-out counters. Although, they only allow up to $50.00 cash return if you use your checking account.

4. Giant Eagle

Giant Eagle gives cashback between $30 to $50. If you are using checks to pay your items, they can allow you cashback amount to a maximum of $30. But if you are using your debit card, they can give you as much as $50 cash return.

It is always best to carry an identification document when going for redeeming a cashback at Giant Eagle; any valid ID will do, such as a driver’s license, a state photo-bearing ID, or a military ID.

5. Hannaford

Hannaford is one of the longest-running supermarkets in the country today, founded by Arthur Hannaford in 1883 on the waterfront of Portland, Maine. The grocery stores also offer cashback for their customers who will be paying through debit cards, Discovery credit cards, and personal checks.

They give a maximum cashback of $100, free of charge. You can use your debit card, Discover Credit Card, or your checks.

6. Kroger

The Kroger supermarket allows a maximum of $300.00 cashback for debit cards, while charging an additional minimal fee of $.50 to $3.50.

Only Discover Credit Cardholders can avail of Kroger’s cashback rewards of up to a maximum of $120 within a 24-hour interval. If you are planning to use a personal check, Kroger can only give you a maximum cashback of $20. You can avail of this reward offer at all Kroger locations.

Suppose ever you would like to avail of the cashback promos of Kroger. In that case, ensure that your purchases do not include alcohol, tobacco products, pharmaceutical products, gift cards, lottery, money service, fees, and fuel. Cash backs do not include items under the “Manager’s Special” or closing out sales promos.

You can avail of cashback rewards at the self-check-out counters, customer service help desk, or right at the cash register check-out counters.

7. Meijeravail

The store offers cashback on debit and personal checking accounts. Their cashback limit is $50.00 for debit cards and $25.00 for checks. They also give cashback for qualified credit cards, which means that your credit card must have some money or prepaid coverage.

The cashback amount for Meijeravail is based on calculating the most current purchase, excluding the number of taxes, shipping, and other coupon discounted items. The cashback rate depends entirely on the current movement of financial fluctuation.

8. Publix

You can avail of cashback at the Publix store. They give back money to a maximum of $100 depending on the stores’ location and size. Most smaller Publix stores have cashback ranging only from $10 to $50.

You can also avail it if you purchase using your debit card, personal checks, and through the Apple Pay app. They do not charge any additional fees on your transaction.

It is best to confirm with a cashier the amount you wish to request for cashback before making the purchase, since overcharging may result in a refusal of the service.

9. Save Mart

Save Mart offers $200 to $300 cashback for debit cards. These amounts also depend on the location and the size of the Save Mart store established in the area.

Save Mart today already has 250 branches within California. They do not charge any fee if you request a cashback, and they’re open until 10 in the evening to serve their valuable clients.

10. Safeway

The store gives cashback of $200 to debit cards, while it offers $120 on Discover Credits Cards. You could go to almost 265 Safeway stores in Hawaii and California until midnight, except for some locations that close between nine and ten in the evening.

11. ShopRite

Shoprite stores have almost 320 stores in the Northeast, allowing you to get as much as $200 cashback if you purchase with a debit card, and the store also gives money back for Discover Credit Cards up to $120. They offer this service free of charge.

The store dedicates itself to serving its precious customers up until midnight at most of its stores. They also offer postage stamp sales and money transfer services.

12. Trader Joe’s

As one of the biggest lines of stores in California, Traders Joe offers explicit shopping experiences to their loyal customers. They do have many incentives, one of which is the most popularly availed by their shoppers — cashback services.

The stores give up to $50 of cashback for debit and credit cards. They start from $10 and have a $10 incremental on every purchase. They accept a range of credit cards, including American Express, Visa Card, Mastercard, and Discover Credit. Trader Joe does this for free and does not incur additional charges for availing these services.

It is best to always inquire from the Traders Joe staff on what items qualify for cashback rewards to ensure that you buy items included in the cashback program.

If you are an employee at Traders Joe, you can also incorporate your employee discount into the cashback policy of the store to get more savings on your money.

Compared to other stores, Traders Joe’s does not give cashback for purchases made with checks because of the extended period to clear it out. They also do not give cashback for cash purchases, but instead provide some incentives to their valuable customers, like discounts and rebates.

You can also take advantage of the following websites to avail yourself cashback at Traders Joe, ShopAtHome, Rakuten, and Ibotta. Simply download those apps, link your credit or debit card and use it for purchase at the store.

13. Whole Foods

It is one of the expansive supermarkets in the country that offers a healthy and organic option for daily items and food products. It has restaurants and coffee shops within the supermarket, so customers can also take some time to grab food while going through racks to purchase as per their needs.

Whole Foods supermarkets give cashback from $1 to $100 depending on how much their customers buy. They do not have a minimum product purchase to avail of this reward, and they also do it free of charge. However, cashback are strictly for purchases made only through a debit card in their store.

14. Winn-Dixie

The Winn Dixie Supermarket is another store that values its customers by giving them cashbacks. They offer cash for purchases done in their stores through debit cards; a customer just needs to present his debit card and request the cashback they need.

The cashback for Winn Dixie does not have a fixed value but depends mainly on the products to be purchased. You must also ensure that what you are buying is included in their cashback promo.

One amazing thing is Winn Dixie also offers cashback on online purchases done with a debit card. You only need to sign up for an account to browse, check on their “Rewards and Deals” tab, and look for the cashback button when you are checking out of your cart. While browsing, you can also check if the product you want to buy is included in the cashback promo.

15. Walmart

Walmart is one of the biggest chains of retail stores around the globe. It started on July 2, 1962, by Sam Walton in Rogers, Arkansas.

Any Walmart Store allows a cashback amounting to $20 to $100 per every debit card transaction. They even enable a client to receive cashbacks three times within the day, provided that they purchase through different debit card transactions. The store does a cashback only in the denomination of $20, so a client can choose from $20, $40,$60,$80, and $100 when requesting the said service.

Walmart stores do cashback for payment using Discover Credit Cards for a maximum of $120 and personal cheques for $20. They offer this service free of charge requiring only that a customer purchases a product of any amount from the store.

Most stores open up until eleven o’clock in the evening, and you can avail a cashback while going through a regular check-out counter or by using self-check-out counters. Walmart does have an ATM within the store premises should you need more cash.

16. Costco

Costco offers cashback for any purchase done via a debit card transaction in their store. They usually allow a 2% cashback for every purchase. Depending on your preference, you can choose to have your cashback from $10 to $60. You can also request a specific denomination and avail of the service multiple times within the day as long as it is approved by your debit card issuing bank.

Costco cash backs can only be availed in their stores but not at their gas station; they had a separate reward card.

17. Staples

Staples is a store that specializes in school and business supplies. They sell staplers, papers, memo pads, rulers, printers, printers, computers, and office furniture.

They give as much as $40 for every transaction made through your debit cards.

18. Dollar tree

Dollar Tree stores offer cashback for every debit card transaction made through their store. A client can avail of as much as $50 for every transaction. It is good to note that you need to pay $1 for every cashback request you will make with Dollar Tree.

The store strictly does not entertain cash back for credit card and cheque purchases.

19. Target

The stores offer cash back services if a client buys from their selection of any item using a debit card. They give as much as $40 in $10 denominations, and they do not require any minimum amount of purchase, nor do they charge an additional fee if you are eligible for a cashback on your purchase.

They also give cashback with a maximum of $20 for personal cheques.

20. Kmart

Kmart stores are where you can get cashback when buying your home necessities. They give as much as $50 for every debit card transaction done in their stores, whether you will take the regular registry or have a self-checked-out option.

They do not give cash back values to credit cards and check purchases in the store.

21. Raley’s Supermarket

Raley’s Supermarket is another large chain of stores found in the US. Loyal customers often bring food products, beverages, and groceries from it, and they can do it both by personally visiting the store or buying through the Raleys Online App. Whichever mode of purchase you chose, Raley’s gives cashback given that you use your debit card to buy from them.

Their cashback ranges from $10 to $60 based on how much the customer purchased from them. Using a debit card bearing a Mastercard logo is entitled to higher cash back at Raley’s. If you are buying directly from the store, you can opt to receive your money back through cash, a gift card, or Paypal.

22. Mariano’s

Mariano’s is a fresh market with coffee bars, bread and sandwich shops, pizzerias baking delicious choices and sushi prepared by on-site chefs. They also have healthy food options for groceries like organic fruits and vegetables and a wide selection of meat and fish, which you can request for assorted meat cuts.

This wet market also has an excellent cashback reward program for its loyal clients. They offer as much as $100 for every Debit Card or a Discover Credit Card Transaction. They may charge additional fees or require a minimum purchase value before you can avail of the cashback

23. HED

Another established grocery store chain in the country is the Heb. It already has 350 branches in Texas And Mexico. HED offers cashback from $5 to $50

HED does not require customers to make a minimum purchase to avail a cashback offer. They also don’t charge additional fees for cashback on debit cards or cheque transactions.

24. Jay C

Jay C food Store has been a division of Krogers since 1999. Prior to that, it was an American supermarket chain that began its operation in 1863 and was founded by John C. Group, a Swiss Immigrant.

The store offers a $100 cashback on debit cards and Discovery Credit Cards transactions. You can avail of their cashback without additional charges or hidden fees.

25. Von

Von operates under the flagship of Albertson Companies. It offers a high cash back rewards of up to $ 200 if your payment is paid via a debit card. You can also avail of their cash back offer with qualified credit cards and personal cheques. But, the maximum amount is only $25.

If you opt to do a self-check-out counter, you may receive an opportunity to cash back as much as $20 to $40. Take note that they don’t charge additional fees for those who want to avail of their cashback reward and there’s also no minimum purchase requirement.

You can also get more than $200 cashback if you will split your purchases in two and transact debit cards twice. You may also choose to re-enter the store, make another purchase, and avail of the service again.

26. CVS

CVS is the largest pharmacy chain in the US with 9,600 locations. They offer cashback of up to $35 if a customer pays with their debit cards. You can avail of this reward for free and there’s no minimum purchase requirement as well.

27. Walgreens

Walgreens is the second-largest pharmacy chain in the US. They also offer a robust cashback program on debit cards. You can avail of their cashback reward even if your purchase is $0.01. The cashback amount you can get ranges from $5 to $20. Unfortunately, they do not offer cashback for credit cards or personal cheques.

Specialty Stores that Offer Cash Backs

You may also avail cashback features from some specialty stores if you link your debit cards with some web app like Ibutta, Rakuten, and Swagbucks. You need to purchase an item through those sites, and the cashback will accrue with your card account. You can also register with Paypal.

Some of the specialty store that offer cash backs include:

Conclusion

Every consumer would desire to redeem every dollar they spend. Taking advantage of the cashback features of these regular stores that you visit to get daily food products, groceries, and miscellaneous items is a wise practice.

It allows you to save bucks and time if you request cashback from them. You just need to make sure that the store accepts your debit or credit card and know how much they could allow you in terms of cashback.

Have all the information you need? Wait no more, grab your grocery bags, cards, or cheques and take advantage of these lucrative cashback offers today!

Originally published at https://www.monetha.io.

Tokeny Solutions

Tokeny’s Talent｜Thaddee’s Story

The post Tokeny’s Talent｜Thaddee’s Story appeared first on Tokeny.
Thaddee Bousselin is Sales Engineer at Tokeny.  Who are you?

My name is Thaddee, I am a 28 year old Frenchman. I am a son, a grandson, a brother, and a partner. I’m also a friend, a travel buddy, and a proud Tokeny coworker!

What were you doing before Tokeny and what inspired you to join the team?

Joining Tokeny was really a logical continuation of my previous experiences. I have traveled my entire life: first following my parents and later for my studies. In total, I spent 10 years in South Korea and China, several years in the United States, and spent my university years in the Czech Republic, Spain, and France. Thanks to these experiences, I learned that diversity and an open-minded entourage are must-haves for me. In high school, I started to notice how technology and new companies were constantly reshaping the way I lived. This inspired me to start studying computer science and entrepreneurship. 

I started to follow Tokeny and the disruptions happening in finance and real estate while writing my master’s thesis. I was motivated to learn more, and therefore started an internship related to tokenization. After that, I knew that I wanted to continue in this ecosystem. Tokeny was the obvious top choice, and it all happened very naturally.

How would you describe working at Tokeny Solutions?

It’s certainly an incredibly fulfilling experience! I feel very fortunate working with  like-minded team members that are so passionate about our mission. For every start-up, there are internal challenges. And, as we have seen in the past years, there will also be new and unforeseen external challenges. I feel reassured being part of a team that has a proven ability to grow together in the face of adversity.

What are you most passionate about in life?

The most important thing to me is to always keep learning and get better at everything I care about. I spend quite some time learning about ways to solve issues such as climate change and finding ways to be proactive about them.

Trying to approach life with a philosophy of gratitude is part of my daily routine, like appreciating the ‘little’ things, good and bad. Of course, I am always looking forward to good times with friends and family. I love listening to and playing music, and on the weekends, you might see me enjoying the thrill of motorcycle driving!

What is your ultimate dream?

Hard question! I’d say being able to look back at my life with a smile, knowing I made the ones around me happy and had even a small but positive impact on society.

What advice would you give to future Tokeny employees?

Welcome aboard 🙂 Getting started can sometimes feel overwhelming. Here are a few things that help me daily: setting priorities, planning the day ahead, asking for help, taking the time to learn things step-by-step, and putting everything into perspective. You will see that learning more about blockchain and technology is really part of everyday life at Tokeny, and it keeps us on our toes!

What gets you excited about Tokeny’s future?

So many different things! Most of all the mix of people working here and the incredible service we provide. In my opinion, tokenization will become mainstream, as what we offer is mind-blowing compared to the traditional approach. Being on the forefront of such an evolution and participating in shaping a better tomorrow for entire industries is, for me, a dream come true.

07:49 • 5 days ago

Okta

Create a Java REST API with Helidon

In this tutorial, I’ll show you how to create a secure REST API and native image with Helidon. You’ll see how to run a secure, OAuth 2.0-protected, Java REST API that allows JWT authentication. Then, I’ll compare its performance with Micronaut, Quarkus, and Spring Boot. This tutorial is also available as a screencast. Prerequisites: SDKMAN (for Java

In this tutorial, I’ll show you how to create a secure REST API and native image with Helidon. You’ll see how to run a secure, OAuth 2.0-protected, Java REST API that allows JWT authentication. Then, I’ll compare its performance with Micronaut, Quarkus, and Spring Boot.

This tutorial is also available as a screencast.

Prerequisites:

SDKMAN (for Java 17 with GraalVM)

HTTPie (a better version of cURL)

An Okta Developer Account (or the Okta CLI)

The brackets at the end of some steps indicate the IntelliJ Live Templates I used in the video. You can find the template definitions at mraible/idea-live-templates. Table of Contents Install a JDK with GraalVM Generate an OAuth 2.0 access token Build a Java REST API with Helidon Run and test your Helidon REST API with HTTPie Build a native Helidon app with GraalVM Startup time comparison Memory usage comparison Comparing Native Java REST API Frameworks Live Stream Secure Native Java with Helidon FTW! Install a JDK with GraalVM

Use SDKMAN to install Java 17 with GraalVM

sdk install java 22.1.0.r17-grl Generate an OAuth 2.0 access token

Install the Okta CLI and run okta register to sign up for a new account. If you already have an account, run okta login.

Run okta apps create spa. Set oidcdebugger as an app name and press Enter.

Use https://oidcdebugger.com/debug for the Redirect URI and set the Logout Redirect URI to https://oidcdebugger.com.

Navigate to the OpenID Connect Debugger website.

Fill in your client ID

Use /oauth2/default/v1/authorize for the Authorize URI

Select code for the response type and Use PKCE

Click Send Request to continue

Set the access token as a TOKEN environment variable in a terminal window.

TOKEN=eyJraWQiOiJYa2pXdjMzTDRBYU1ZSzNGM... Build a Java REST API with Helidon

Create a Helidon app with OAuth 2.0 support:

mvn -U archetype:generate -DinteractiveMode=false \ -DarchetypeGroupId=io.helidon.archetypes \ -DarchetypeArtifactId=helidon-quickstart-mp \ -DarchetypeVersion=2.5.0 \ -DgroupId=com.okta.rest \ -DartifactId=helidon \ -Dpackage=com.okta.rest You can also install Helidon’s CLI and run helidon init.

Add MicroProfile JWT support in pom.xml:

<dependency> <groupId>io.helidon.microprofile.jwt</groupId> <artifactId>helidon-microprofile-jwt-auth</artifactId> </dependency>

Add a HelloResource class that returns the user’s information: [h-hello]

package com.okta.rest.controller; import io.helidon.security.Principal; import io.helidon.security.SecurityContext; import javax.ws.rs.GET; import javax.ws.rs.Path; import javax.ws.rs.Produces; import javax.ws.rs.core.Context; import java.util.Optional; import static javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType.TEXT_PLAIN; @Path("/hello") public class HelloResource { @GET @Produces(TEXT_PLAIN) public String hello(@Context SecurityContext context) { Optional<Principal> userPrincipal = context.userPrincipal(); return "Hello, " + userPrincipal.get().getName() + "!"; } }

Add a HelloApplication class in src/main/java/com/okta/rest to register your resource and configure JWT authentication: [h-app]

package com.okta.rest; import com.okta.rest.controller.HelloResource; import org.eclipse.microprofile.auth.LoginConfig; import javax.enterprise.context.ApplicationScoped; import javax.ws.rs.core.Application; import java.util.Set; @LoginConfig(authMethod = "MP-JWT") @ApplicationScoped public class HelloApplication extends Application { @Override public Set<Class<?>> getClasses() { return Set.of(HelloResource.class); } }

Add your Okta endpoints to src/main/resources/META-INF/microprofile-config.properties.

mp.jwt.verify.publickey.location=/oauth2/default/v1/keys mp.jwt.verify.issuer=/oauth2/default Run and test your Helidon REST API with HTTPie

Start your app from your IDE or using a terminal:

mvn package && java -jar ./target/helidon.jar

Test your API with an access token.

http :8080/hello Authorization:"Bearer $TOKEN" Build a native Helidon app with GraalVM

Compile your Helidon app into a native executable using the native-image profile:

mvn package -Pnative-image

Start your Helidon app:

./target/helidon

Test your API with an access token.

http :8080/hello Authorization:"Bearer $TOKEN" Startup time comparison

I compared startup times between frameworks by running each image three times before recording the numbers. Then, I ran each app five more times and averaged the results. I gathered these numbers on a 2019 MacBook Pro with an SSD, 2.4 GHz 8-Core Intel Core i9 processor, and 64 GB of RAM.

Versions used: Quarkus 2.9.0, Micronaut 3.4.3, Helidon 2.5.0, and Spring Boot 2.6.7 with Spring Native 0.11.5.

Memory usage comparison

I tested the memory usage (in megabytes) of each app using the command below. I ran it right after I started the app, after a single authenticated request, and after five authenticated requests.

ps -o pid,rss,command | grep --color <executable> | awk '{$2=int($2/1024)"M";}{ print;}'

The chart below shows the memory usage after five requests.

What about the MacBook Pro M1 Max?

My MacBook Pro (16-inch, 2021) with Apple M1 Max builds much faster, apps start up 2x faster, but they use more memory.

Comparing Native Java REST API Frameworks Live Stream

I missed Devoxx France this year, but I’m still doing my presentation! I’ll be live-streaming Comparing Native Java REST API Frameworks on June 7, 2022 at 6:00 MDT (14:00 CEST). Join me or watch the recorded version below!

Secure Native Java with Helidon FTW!

⚡️ Create a secure REST API with Helidon: okta start helidon

🚀 Find this example’s code on GitHub: @oktadev/native-java-examples/helidon

👀 Related blog post: Build REST APIs and Native Java Apps with Helidon

05:00 • 5 days ago

Wednesday, 01. June 2022

Finicity

The Rise of Open Banking: Powering Small Business With Access to Capital

The United States is home to 32.5 million small businesses, which amounts to 99.9% of all businesses in the country. They employ just under half of the workforce, and are responsible for 44% of total GDP. Clearly, supporting the growth of small-to-midsize businesses is essential to the lifeblood of the economy.  The important role of […] The post The Rise of Open Banking: Powering Small Bus

The United States is home to 32.5 million small businesses, which amounts to 99.9% of all businesses in the country. They employ just under half of the workforce, and are responsible for 44% of total GDP. Clearly, supporting the growth of small-to-midsize businesses is essential to the lifeblood of the economy. 

The important role of the small business in the economy isn’t always reflected by lending guidelines that work for the small business owner, however. Thirty percent of businesses that apply for credit through traditional lenders are denied, or only qualify for a portion of the funds they need. These numbers drop even further for minorities looking for the operating capital they need to grow their businesses. 

In an increasingly data-driven, digital economy, there’s room for additional choice. Innovative lending solutions can give every owner an equal opportunity to make their business dreams a reality. 

Open Banking is Giving Lenders and Small Business Owners More Choice

According to Mastercard’s Rise of Open Banking study, 74% of small-to-midsize business (SMB) owners would share business performance data if it meant that they could better demonstrate their ability to pay back a loan and have more choice in lending options. Black, hispanic and millennial owners are even more enthusiastic about sharing financial data, if sharing it means being presented with better loan terms and options. Over 80% responded positively to data sharing in each of those demographic categories. 

Owner-permissioned data through Mastercard’s open banking platform can power apps and services with up to 24 months of rich cash flow attributes. This can inform better, more accurate insights which lenders can use to make financial decisions. Approvals, credit increases, leases and other small business needs can be granted with reduced risk of bad debt. 

Data can be used to develop new lending models and underwrite new lending products. This opens up access to capital with terms and options that can be crafted to fit unique SMB needs. Funding is an ongoing issue for small business owners. Eighty-five percent are looking for faster, easier access to capital, and 62% have received a business loan. 

Whether it comes from public-facing consumer retail, ecommerce, professional services or seasonal businesses, owner-permissioned open banking data is the launchpad for a fast-growing ecosystem of effective financial tools that simply didn’t exist in the pre-digital era. 

Rather than basing lending decisions on metrics like personal credit scores, business credit scores and time in business, lenders are using open banking data points and analytics to unlock capital. Businesses that may have been impeded by traditional guidelines that aren’t aligned with the modern economy now have new options for funding. They’re benefiting from advances in open banking data technology, and they’re asking for the financial opportunities and insights that data can provide.

Small Business Owners Want to Grow With Tools and Allies

Despite the challenges of rising costs, talent acquisition, supply chain issues, cybersecurity and a host of other concerns, owners are optimistic and ready to grow. Forty-seven percent say they’re in growth mode, and looking for allies to help them scale up. 

Over 80% of owners say they want a partner to help them find access to capital and to loans that fit the needs of their specific business. This is where open banking solutions stand out, and where innovators are expanding the lending ecosystem with data-driven loan products, like:

Low-interest loans Micro-loans Credit card options Niche lending

In just a three-month period at the beginning of 2020, U.S.-based fintech Lendio helped over 100,000 small businesses connect to over $8 billion in U.S. Paycheck Protection Program loans, using owner-permissioned open banking data to analyze cash flow and other alternative lending metrics.

Small business specialists like Lendio have been a badly-needed lifeline during the pandemic and beyond. An open banking platform makes it possible to close the smaller loans that financial institutions don’t typically originate, and to do it more quickly. The manpower needed to run open banking-powered apps and services is less intensive than what is required to handle the traditional underwriting process at larger institutions. The amount of work that it takes to underwrite smaller loans has made them less appealing to some lenders in the past. 

This has caused some business owners to be left behind, particularly women and minorities seeking less capital to fund their enterprises. 

Open banking provides real-time data that helps lenders understand a small to mid-sized business’ creditworthiness, letting them more quickly and easily approve loans, no matter the size. With small business loans ranging from $5,000 to $1.2 million, it’s clear there is a wide range of opportunities to ally with owners by offering specialized lending products. 

Addressing a Growing Need in the Small Business Sector

There’s a growing list of lenders covering every need and every niche that the market is asking for, and demand has never been higher. According to the Mastercard study, eighty-seven percent of owners already use or would like to use open banking-powered fintech apps and services to secure funding for their businesses. 

Small businesses are still recovering from the effects of the pandemic, with the percentage of cash-strapped enterprises moving up slightly, from 15% to 18%. Innovators have an opportunity to create solutions that help owners who need reserves and operating capital, but who may have a short tenure in business, a thin credit file or low FICO scores. 

Owners want to secure and refinance loans. They want allies to help them make informed decisions. Ninety-six percent of them are linking their accounts and sharing their data. Alongside the desire for funding, 85% are looking for the customized financial recommendations that can come from sharing data with open banking apps and services. They want access to capital, and they want it quicker and smarter, to keep pace with an unpredictable consumer marketplace. 

 

In the next installment of the Rise of Open Banking series, we look at how open banking is transforming the payments experience for the SMB. Click here to download the full study.

The post The Rise of Open Banking: Powering Small Business With Access to Capital appeared first on Finicity.

23:08 • 5 days ago

KuppingerCole

Why Architects Should Rethink Authorizations

In the digital era, organizations are increasingly interacting online with contractors, partners, and customers. Traditional role-based authorization frameworks are not designed to provide these external identities with the right access to resources, services, and apps. A new approach is required.

In the digital era, organizations are increasingly interacting online with contractors, partners, and customers. Traditional role-based authorization frameworks are not designed to provide these external identities with the right access to resources, services, and apps. A new approach is required.

Explainer Understanding Verifiable Credentials by Credivera 

The value of verifiable credentials and the critical role they will play to our future digital identities is undeniable. As we enter a new era of online representation, trust in the internet will need to be vigorously robust.

Rewiring the Internet with Self-Sovereign Identities.

In “Self-Sovereign Identity,” Johannes Sedlmeir makes a clear distinction between two concepts too often mixed: “identity” and “identifiers”. What we are experiencing in today’s Web are some external organizations identifying us as citizens, community members, customers, etc. But this isn’t our “identity.” Those are identifiers. 

Digital Identities and Verifiable Credentials Johannes Sedlmeir • Reilly Smethurst • Alexander Rieger • Gilbert Fridgen Published October 2021 Fundamentals of Decentralized Identity: Free Certification Course Dock.io

Myths about SSI Jolocom

The idea that as a user of SSI I have complete sovereignty over my digital identity is often misunderstood. At its core, SSI is about my digital identity being under my own control, so I can decide to whom I show my data, when, and for what.

Design From the Margins Centering the most marginalized and impacted in design processes - from ideation to production Can digital identity help with the world refugee crisis? SecurityBoulevard

The first international agreement on how refugees could handle the issue of missing or incomplete identity documents resulted from the Arrangement of 5 July, 1922, which was a meeting of the League of Nations. Among other things, the conference established a uniform “identity certificate” for Russian refugees, between one and two million of whom had been displaced by various conflicts over the previous decade.

we present an architecture for constructing and customizing SSI services with a set of architectural patterns and provide corresponding evaluations. Furthermore, we demonstrate the feasibility of our proposed architecture in practice with Selfid, an SSIaaS platform based on our proposed architecture.

18:27 • 6 days ago

Finicity

Freddie Mac Now Accepts 10-Day Pre-Close Verification of Employment for Home Loans

Mastercard’s open banking platform (provided by Mastercard’s wholly-owned subsidiary, Finicity) offers pre-close reports that provide just the right data that GSEs need for 10-day verification of employment. Today, Freddie Mac announced the acceptance of our Verification of Employment (VOE) Reports.    In adding the VOE Payroll and Transactions reports to our Mortgage Verification Servic

Mastercard’s open banking platform (provided by Mastercard’s wholly-owned subsidiary, Finicity) offers pre-close reports that provide just the right data that GSEs need for 10-day verification of employment. Today, Freddie Mac announced the acceptance of our Verification of Employment (VOE) Reports. 

 

In adding the VOE Payroll and Transactions reports to our Mortgage Verification Services (MVS) product, we have enabled lenders to receive only the data GSEs require for the 10-day verification. Lenders can use these reports to view only your borrower’s employment status, rather than refreshing the full reports that contain more data than required for an employment verification. This minimizes the introduction of new income data or other redundant and unnecessary underwriting changes that could delay the loan closing or cause additional work.

 

The two available reports provide different types of information. The VOE Transactions report contains 120 days of refreshed transactions with dates and description, but no amounts or totals so income is not reassessed. It shows the latest direct deposits in the income streams, to confirm the  borrower is still being paid on their regular cadence.

 

Another option is the VOE Payroll report. This contains only employment status and details—no income or other data—so lenders can see that the individual is still employed according to their payroll provider.

 

These two reports are part of MVS at no extra charge and are currently available for lenders connecting directly to Mastercard and through Ice Mortgage Technology.

 

The VOE Transaction and Payroll reports can help lenders improve accuracy and simplify the process of verifying employment within ten days of closing, removing more friction from the loan origination process without increasing risk. With one click, a GSE-accepted VOE report is available in moments, avoiding the lost time and the uncertainty of tracking down verbal verifications from employers.

 

How can you access these 10-day pre-closing reports?

 

To pull the VOE reports today, your team will need to code directly to the endpoints or add this functionality through Encompass LOS from Ice Technology. You can find documentation here. To see Mastercard’s Mortgage Verification Services in action, request a demo here.

Want to learn what borrowers want from a digitized mortgage process powered by open banking solutions? Click here.

The post Freddie Mac Now Accepts 10-Day Pre-Close Verification of Employment for Home Loans appeared first on Finicity.

Spruce Systems

Spruce Developer Update #20

At Spruce, we’re letting users control their identity and data across the web. Here’s the latest from our development efforts: Sign-In with Ethereum We have released our streamlined SIWE Core packages across all supported programming languages to have unified handling of message creation, parsing, and verification.

At Spruce, we’re letting users control their identity and data across the web. Here’s the latest from our development efforts:

Sign-In with Ethereum We have released our streamlined SIWE Core packages across all supported programming languages to have unified handling of message creation, parsing, and verification. Additionally, we released a v2.0 beta of our TypeScript library. Sign-In with Ethereum - API Harmonization and TypeScript v2.0 Beta Release In our continued updates on Sign-In with Ethereum support, we’re pleased to announce that we’ve harmonized the behavior of our SIWE Core APIs across different languages, added a number of optimizations, and have released a new beta of our TypeScript library with the included changes. SpruceSpruce We've set up a release pipeline and had our first witnessed deployment for the ENS Community-Maintained OIDC IdP. For more information on this initiative, check out this post: Sign-In with Ethereum - Decentralizing an Identity Provider Server While digging deeper on Sign-In with Ethereum adoption vectors for Web2, we found that many traditional services wanted to integrate Sign-In with Ethereum. Most already supported OpenID Connect (OIDC) and were open to adding a new Identity Provider (IdP) that supported the workflow. While we encoura… SpruceRocco We are still working on additional integrations with partners and frameworks. If you're interested in a specific integration, please get in touch! Kepler

Kepler is a decentralized storage network organized around data overlays called Orbits. Kepler allows users to Securely share their digital credentials, private files, and sensitive media to blockchain accounts, all using a Web3 wallet.

We've added basic tracing to Kepler kepler#114. We've expanded the Authorization Capabilities tracking subsystem functionality, making the authorization graph the attestation root of the service graphs. We've moved our core Kepler SDK functionality into Rust to more easily use SSI functionality and to enable building SDKs for other languages in the future. We've implemented support for CACAO-ZCAPs, improved the `put` function to make it easier to store objects of different types, and added support for listing objects by prefix: kepler-sdk#40 kepler#115. On cryptoscript, we've merged Rustdoc documentation for the stack-based language and JSON query support (cryptoscript#2). Additionally, we've implemented an experimental front-end syntax for the language which supports variables, assignments, and more (cryptoscript#4). SpruceID

SpruceID is a decentralized identity toolkit that provides everything you need for signing, sharing, and verifying trusted information.

DIDKit Enabled ES384 JWS algorithm (ssi#431). Added runtime-configurable context loader (ssi#432, didkit#298) (Thanks vdods/LedgerDomain!) (In progress) Add CACAO-ZCAP integration (ssi#436). Added JFF VC-EDU Plugfest 2022 context (ssi#440), (ssi#443)  (Thanks TaylorBeeston/WeLibrary!). Standards and Community Updated the JWS-Test-Suite to show more interop and spec conformance (#60, #62). Testing W3C CCG VC-EDU JFF PlugFest example credentials (#30, #32). Rebase The initial library demonstrating the creation of VCs from witness flows is complete, with additional work on a self-serve UI currently ongoing.

Spruce lets users control their data across the web. Through SpruceID and Kepler, Spruce provides an ecosystem of open source tools for developers that let users collect their data in one place that they control, and show their cards however they want.

If you're curious about integrating Spruce's technology into your project, come chat with us in our Discord:



16:41 • 6 days ago

Monetha

Customer Retention Management: Tips to Reduce Churn and Increase Loyalty

Each year, new platforms and businesses join the ecommerce arena, making it more crowded. This eventually leads to an increase in the cost of clicks and conversions, which is why it is far more economical to get existing consumers to place a repeat purchase than it is to acquire new buyers. However, have you ever evaluated your marketing techniques and engaged with your customer base to enti

Each year, new platforms and businesses join the ecommerce arena, making it more crowded. This eventually leads to an increase in the cost of clicks and conversions, which is why it is far more economical to get existing consumers to place a repeat purchase than it is to acquire new buyers.

However, have you ever evaluated your marketing techniques and engaged with your customer base to entice them to return to your store? If you believe you have not done enough, now is an excellent opportunity to develop comprehensive customer retention management strategies. Let’s start with the basics.

What is Customer Retention Management?

The concept of customer retention management centers around how a customer continues to engage with a business and how that business may gain additional value from its returning customers. According to experts, learning how to manage client retention is critical to a company’s long-term viability.

Customer retention is important in both contractual and non-contractual relationships. Client retention in a contractual relationship is defined by whether or not the consumer agrees to renew the arrangement, whereas the customer has the flexibility to just stop transacting with a business in a non-contractual relationship.

In a nutshell, customer retention management is ensuring that the consumers you fought so hard to stick with you, have a high level of customer satisfaction, and continue to cherish your products and services. In some circumstances, it may also entail ensuring that the consumer does not flee to your competitor.

Churn, on the other hand, is the polar opposite of customer retention. This is when a customer decides to stop doing business with a company. When it comes to retention management, churn is your number one enemy.

What Metrics Help You Measure Customer Retention?

Measuring customer retention is crucial for businesses since it helps anticipate how long someone will be a loyal client and, ultimately, calculates a company’s long-term profitability and value. It can also be used to assess the health of a business.

There are different formulas used by experts for measuring retention. However, the traditional equation focuses on the number of customers at the beginning (CS) and end of a period (CE), as well as the number of new customers you get (CN).

Customer Retention Formula

The formula for calculating customer retention is as follows:

((CE-CN)/CS)) X 100

Don’t be concerned if you’re not a math genius. We will use a short case study to assist you to learn how to use the formula.

Assume you own a barbershop with 200 repeat clients at the start of last year. Throughout the year, you notice that 20 of those customers are missing, but you also have 40 new customers that come to your place every month. This means you’ll have 220 loyal clients by the end of the year.

Let’s do the math and enter the numbers into the formula

((220–40)/200)) X 100

You should get a 90 as the answer, which indicates your customer retention rate for the period is 90%. Is it suitable for a barbershop? It all depends on the industry and the data from previous years.

Important Factors for Customer Retention

Measuring customer retention is important because if you cannot measure it, it simply means you cannot manage it. However, besides the formula, below you will find some other important factors when measuring your customer retention strategies.

1. Product engagement

Customer retention is heavily influenced by how frequently and intensely your consumers buy your service or product. As a result, the greater the frequency and intensity, the higher the product engagement will be.

Big companies like Facebook and TikTok rely heavily on product engagement to maintain a high number of loyal customers. They accomplish this by creating habit-forming technologies that are intrinsically engineered to keep people encouraged to return.

2. Service quality

Service quality is the next most significant element influencing customer retention. While quality is a somewhat subjective concept, certain characteristics, such as a smooth shopping experience and a high level of customization, can positively influence it.

Customers in the ecommerce industry are concerned not just with the things they purchase, but also with the process of purchasing them, which is why a pleasant shopping experience is essential. To put it another way, the fewer steps required to purchase the product, the more likely the client will return.

Customers also like it when a company understands exactly what they are looking for. If you’ve ever wondered why large ecommerce companies invest so much money to create an algorithm that knows what someone is looking for, this is the answer.

3. Relationship quality

Quality relationship development begins the first moment a consumer walks into your store. Luckily, a warm greeting, a discount coupon after purchase, or even a simple “thank you” should help you make a lasting, positive impression.

Of course, you should deliver excellent service along the way. Offering multiple communication channels, training your personnel to execute operations effectively, and never ignoring any customer request are some of the keys to accomplishing this.

Having a specialized customer service team will greatly assist you in creating strong bonds with your client base. This team should not only ensure that the consumer is satisfied, but should also look for ways to win the hearts of your customers.

4. Branding

One thing any entrepreneur should understand is that people tend to stick with brands they are familiar with. This is why putting significant effort into your branding should help you get more repeat consumers.

Clearly presenting your brand helps people in determining whether or not they would think about buying your items. Aside from that, branding will help clients understand what your company advocates for. As a result of these elements, many buyers can make a more informed purchasing decision.

Knowing how to develop compelling and educational material is also critical. It keeps your clients up to date on your products and, hopefully, keeps them engaged in a continuous and participating cycle.

5. Switching cost

If it costs a fortune to get an alternative to your goods, a customer will not move to another brand. Maintaining a loyal consumer should not be difficult if an entrepreneur can give great products, quality service, and strong branding while keeping costs reasonable.

Best Practices to Improve Your Customer Retention

Every new consumer represents a potential long-term customer. Even if a customer does not return, you should make every effort to leave a positive impression. Certain best practices below can help put you and your company up for success in terms of customer retention.

The first practice is to make it a priority for your team to maintain and improve the customer experience. It is never only about how much your clients can spend on your products; it is also about what your staff can accomplish for them.

Your business plan should also be more focused on becoming scalable and capable of supporting the company’s shifting objectives. You must develop ways of measuring the impacts of these adjustments and continue to respond as needed. More importantly, your staff must be adaptable to these developments.

After you’ve determined what your team is capable of and what your company’s goals are, it’s time to streamline your company’s operations. After streamlining processes, your team should have consistent measures in place for everything from acquiring new customers to minimizing churn.

Finally, to build a consistent client base, you must maintain customer ties. In terms of shopping habits and experience, you should always be aware of where your buyers are as well as where they are going. This will assist you in ensuring that their path does not take them out the door.

Integrating these tried-and-true practices into your daily operations should help you prove to your consumers that you are the smartest option. Seek out developing technologies that provide early warning signals for red flags in shopping behavior and recommend appropriate next measures for the best results.

The 15 Best Customer Retention Management Strategies for Businesses

You should never underestimate the value of a devoted consumer base. According to studies, loyal customers account for 68 percent of sales, so maintaining existing clients should be your top priority. Read on for the greatest strategies for maintaining a high level of customer loyalty.

1. Set realistic expectations for your customers

It can be unlikely to please someone you hardly know at times, so you may think it’s normal to create high expectations for them. However, if you want to set and satisfy client expectations, it is best to be truthful while making a promise.

Only guarantee what you can do and give your customers expectations that you can meet. If you are unable to fulfill expectations, apologize and recompense your customers.

If a customer expects a high-quality product and service but receives a subpar product, the disappointment will linger for a long time. They will eventually find it impossible to forget false promises and, worse, will leave negative reviews about your company.

2. Build trust slowly and carefully through relationships

Customers agree that trust is a crucial aspect of their judgment when making a purchase. However, developing trust is not a process that any company can undertake overnight.

You allow new and existing clients to trust you when you create interactions with them. Unfortunately, if clients realize you’re not trustworthy, they’ll go to your competitors.

After all, consistency in offering value to customers is a major aspect of creating trust, so your business should be persistent in meeting customer needs. As previously said, continuously delivering on your marketing promise over time will influence whether or not your clients see your company as trustworthy.

3. Improve your customer service department’s KPIs

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are measurable benchmarks that show how well a company is able to meet corporate objectives. These criteria are necessary so that businesses can assess their progress in meeting targets.

KPIs can be thought of as a road map to your goals. They assist you in seeing what the future brings for your company and the path you should take.

Developing working KPIs for your customer service division quantifies a variety of criteria depending on your sector. However, they mostly involve response time, conversion rate, and funnel drop rate.

The results will astound you once you start measuring these KPIs. It will be easier to determine how to better engage customers and what actions must be taken.

4. Make use of customer feedback surveys

Client feedback surveys may appear boring, and their response rate is not always high, yet they can offer you valuable customer input. It can be a great instrument for increasing customer interaction and driving business actions.

Hearing personally from clients about how they feel about your offerings is a terrific approach to strengthen the connections that already exist. When people are given the opportunity to communicate themselves, they share their thoughts and opinions about your brand.

It is critical not to frown when your consumers complain. Learn about their dissatisfaction and be perceptive enough to discover their pain points. Making changes in such areas will assist you in improving customer relationships.

5. Develop real-time customer engagement protocols

One of the most renowned client retention tactics is to use real-time customer engagement solutions. Live sessions have been shown to have a significant influence on customer satisfaction, and quick response decreases the number of client touchpoints.

Some financial organizations, for example, have co-browsing and video chat solutions in place. Their primary objectives are to promote user involvement through internet banking activities and to provide a cutting-edge digital banking experience.

Face-to-face interactions also promote individualized conversations with customers. Interestingly, research has shown that video chat solutions also help anxieties and concerns settle faster, allowing you to develop personal and dependable relations with clients.

6. Try to outperform your claims

The secret to not disappointing your customers is to under promise and over deliver. When you follow this approach, you are surpassing customer expectations, giving your company the opportunity to gain a more loyal customer base.

It is critical to keep your promises and to dare to exceed them. Never miss a chance to delight your consumers. Treat them as special individuals, and you will undoubtedly increase customer retention.

Be aware that the initial purchase of your product is a delicate stage. When they are disappointed, they can become hostile. So, something as easy as delivering your product a few days sooner than promised will make your consumer delighted.

7. Make a schedule for customer interactions

You use a communication calendar to stay in touch with your consumers on a routine basis. Even if your clients do not provide feedback, your team should be assertive in interacting with them.

The calendar is essentially a pre-programmed series of phone calls, events, and so on. Through continuous contact and exchanges, it is expected that doubts will be removed, trust levels will be increased, and the consumer will be persuaded to return.

Luckily, you can now effortlessly automate frequent contacts with your consumers. There are various communication calendar solutions available online today that enable you to deliver unique offers and appreciation messages to customers on a certain schedule.

8. Learn something from any customer complaint

Only bad business owners feel the urge to flee from complaining customers. If you want to be a successful businessman, you should go for these clients since they might be your most valuable marketing asset.

Complaints highlight what you should change and what you need to discard in your company. You may learn what your consumers care about and what they anticipate from your services by analyzing client complaints.

Some consumers leave without leaving a comment, which is bad for your business. Encourage people to share their concerns because this is how you learn about flaws in your products and services.

9. Figure out the CLV of your business

Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) is one of these critical key performance metrics that demonstrates the importance of your clients over time. For example, if you provide subscription-based online courses, your primary focus should be on each customer’s lifetime value.

Some of your consumers have contributed more than others. Those who consistently purchase your stuff should be considered VIP customers.

This is because they not only provide you with continuous income, but they are also the same clients who will promote your business to others. They tell their peers about their experience, which helps your brand’s credibility.

10. Consistently deliver valuable information

Just because a customer has made a transaction with you does not suggest you should abandon your efforts to seal the deal. Because people have more alternatives than ever before, go the additional mile and provide them with something meaningful.

Education is one of the most significant services you can provide to your customers. The goal here is to advise and engage people until they are ready to buy your product.

It provides clients with knowledge and insights into the product to help them comprehend it. Once they become loyal, they can also turn into your brand advocates.

11. Re-engage customers by leveraging automation technologies

It takes time to manually check and keep your consumers informed. There are numerous actions that must be performed daily to keep your brand relevant in the minds of your customers. This is where automation technology can come in handy.

They enable software to handle parts of your processes automatically. You may manage your customer contacts, continue giving education letters, schedule marketing offers, and send other notifications using automation.

Not only will you notice an improvement in conversion rate as you engage clients automatically, but you will also be able to form stronger ties. Moreover, making these processes more efficient will allow you to deliver on the promises you make to your clients.

12. Monitor and evaluate churn metrics

Businesses that want to optimize retention efforts must understand how to analyze and measure churn data. You should be measuring and evaluating the number of consumers who churn as well as the reasons why they churn.

You can improve the customer experience by learning why consumers leave and how they leave. More importantly, it teaches you how to keep your current consumers from leaving.

Customer churn will come regardless of your best attempts. When this occurs, you should take advantage of the chance to investigate what you can do to prevent a comparable customer from leaving for the same reason in the future.

13. Provide customized, one-of-a-kind services to loyal customers

Scientists believe that surprise is beneficial to the brain. It provides enjoyment and spice to one’s life. So, instead of waiting for your clients to make a request, go ahead and delight them with personalized service.

Unexpected offers can give your clients the impression that they are a part of something special. Therefore, if you want your clients to stick around and love your brand, you should go above and beyond the standard service that you provide.

A well-designed client retention campaign can be a fantastic idea. By rewarding your consumers with one-of-a-kind discounts and prizes, you make them feel good about their purchases and encourage them to return.

14. Use newsletters to keep in touch with customers

Generating email newsletters is still the most effective client retention method. It is one of the most effective strategies to stay in touch with consumers and develop long-term connections with them.

It is essential to follow up with new clients and email subscribers after the initial interaction. If you want to cultivate client loyalty, you must keep your subscribers up to date on the latest and hottest information from your brand.

Email newsletters enable you to convey relevant information to your intended audience. You can categorize the list based on characteristics such as buying habits and age demographics, and then tailor the newsletter to each category.

15. Create a community to improve customer interactions

Creating a forum on your webpage is an easy approach to fostering engagement and community. Having a forum allows your customers to discuss your products, services, and everything else about your brand.

One example of a very active platform used by store owners to communicate with customers is a discussion board. The platform allows users to post challenges, questions, and fresh ideas. This media can also be used to share information about new product features, promotions, and expansions.

You may even spice up the conversation by rewarding your most active users. This would encourage more active engagement, which would increase your customers’ loyalty to your brand.

Look around and you’ll find that prosperous digital companies got there not only because of their excellent services, but also because their customers collaborated. They employ community platforms to connect with customers, eventually transforming them into brand advocates.

However, you will almost certainly come across bad remarks or complaints. When you find one, don’t dismiss it; instead, confront it. Users will learn, respect, and trust your brand this way.

Conclusion

Now that you’re armed with a list full of useful retention management strategies, which would you go for first? There is no one-size-fits-all solution that will work for every business, but as long as you keep the customer’s interests in mind, they will return.

To proactively treat customers, you must provide excellent customer service and build interpersonal kindness. With well-designed client retention strategies, you will better understand your consumers’ needs and enhance loyalty.

Originally published at https://www.monetha.io.
